ORDER
Petitioner challenges the proceedings in C.C.No.1464/2021 on
the files of Judicial First Class Magistrate Court,
Nedumkandam, arising out of Crime No.197/2021 of
Nedumkandam Police Station, registered for the offences
punishable under Sections 188, 269, 271, 294(b), 506(1),
341, 353, 323, 332, 427 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 and
Sections 4(2)e r/w Section 3(a) the Kerala Epidemic Diseases
Ordinance 2021.

2. According to the prosecution, on 29.04.2021 during a vehicle
check, the accused failed to stop the vehicle, and thereafter,
when the vehicle was found parked on the side of a road,
the Police removed the same. On account of the said
enmity the accused abused and threatened the de facto

complainant and other police officers, after blocking their
vehicle and also assaulted them and, even tore the name
plate from the uniform of the de facto complainant thereby
committed the offences alleged. Since the 1° accused was
violated the quarantine requirements of Covid-19 as he was
suffering from the infection, the offences under Kerala
Epidemic Diseases Ordinance 2021 was also attracted.

3. Sri.Sachithananda Pai, the learned counsel for the
petitioners, submitted that the allegations are false and that
the case against the petitioners has been lodged with a mala
fide intent. It was further submitted that none of the
offences alleged against the petitioners are made out, and
hence the proceedings against the petitioners ought to be
quashed.

4. Smt.Sreeja V., the learned Public Prosecutor, opposed the
application and submitted that the nature of allegations as
revealed from Annexure-1 final report indicates that
appreciation of evidence is required, which can be done only
after trial.

5. Petitioner is alleged to have abused the de facto complainant
and other police officers and even tore the name plate from
CW1. According to the prosecution, when the accused was
found, during a vehicle check, roaming around in violation
of Covid-19 restriction. He refused to stop the vehicle, and
later the vehicle was found parked on the side of the road
and was taken into custody. In retaliation, the accused
assaulted the de facto complainant and other police officers
and even tore the name plate of the police officers.
Whether such allegations are true or false is a matter that
can be appreciated only after adducing evidence.

6. It is settled that the remedy under Section 482 of Cr.P.C.,
cannot be invoked unless the admitted allegations do not
make out any of the offences alleged. A reading of the
allegations as seen in the final report indicates that the
offences can be made out if those allegations are admitted.
Therefore, it is only after trial can any court can appreciate
whether those are proved or not. Thus Section 482 of
Cr.P.C. is certainly not a remedy available to the petitioners.
